Author/Title Index: R

All data was derived from the List of Identifications (PDF) by Professor Richard Sharpe.

    1 catalogue entry (1 book).
    • Practica grammaticae, Verbarius: not known to survive.
      Catalogue entryCatalogue

  • `Ralph Acton'
    1 catalogue entry (2 books).
    • Sermones dominicales → Radulphus Ardens
    • Sermones de sanctis: not identified; Sharpe, Latin Writers, 443.
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      SS1.1197 (`Acton super epistolas et euangeliis sanctorum') BRIGITTINES: Syon: Registrum of the library of the Brethren, c. 1500-c. 1524
  • Radulphus Ardens [late 12th cent.]
    DS 13 (1988) 97–106.
    4 catalogue entries (1 book).
    • Sermones dominicales: PL 155. 1301–2118; Schneyer Rep. 5. 1–8. Several medieval copies in England were marked `Acton', leading Leland to attribute the sermons to `Ralph Acton', who appears to be a ghost; Sharpe, Latin Writers, 443. [List of manuscripts by R. J. Stansbury in Studi medievali 3rd ser. 42 (2001) 875–96.]
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      B60.6 (`omeliae Radulphi Actonis') BENEDICTINES: THE SHORTER CATALOGUES: Norwich: Leland, c. 1536-40
      SC335.107 (`Acton super epistolas et euangelia') SECULAR INSTITUTIONS: Secular Colleges: Winchester College: Inventory of the library, 30 July 1428 × 24 August 1429
      SS1.1059 (`Acton super epistolas et euangelia dominicalia . .') BRIGITTINES: Syon: Registrum of the library of the Brethren, c. 1500-c. 1524
      UC48.*136 UNIVERSITY AND COLLEGE LIBRARIES OF CAMBRIDGE: Peterhouse: Catalogue, 24 Dec. 1418

  • Remius Favinus [?]
    The best manuscripts identify the author as `Remi Favini' (in the genitive); included in early printed editions of Priscian, [Venice] 1470 (Goff P960), &c., and independently pr. [Leipzig 1494] (ISTC), the writer's name had become Rhemnius Fannius, identified in the early 16th cent. with the 1st-cent. grammarian Q. Remmius Palaemon.
    1 catalogue entry (1 book).
    • Carmen de ponderibus: ed. A. Riese, Anthologia Latina siue Poesis Latinae Supplementum (Leipzig 1894–1906), 1/2. 29–37.
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      B39.*156f (`Rufinus de ponderibus et mensuris') BENEDICTINES: THE SHORTER CATALOGUES: Glastonbury: Catalogue, 1247, with additions

  • Richard of Cirencester [?]
    1 catalogue entry (1 book).
    • Liber de officio ecclesiastico, inc. `Officium ut': not known to survive, but cited by William Woodford, in his Contra Trialogum Wyclif, `per Richardum de Cirencestria de officiis' (ed. Brown, 1. 193), and elsewhere as `Ricardus de Cirencestria de officio ecclesie' (Postilla on Matthew, fol. 104rb), or `de officio misse' (ib. fol. 132vb), &c. (J. I. Catto, William Woodford, OFM (c.1330–c.1397), DPhil diss. (Oxford 1969), 324–5). He is also cited in Woodford's Quaestiones LXXII de sacramento altaris, Bodl. MS Bodley 703, fol. 160va, `per Ricardum de Cyrencestria qui egregie scripsit libros de diuinis officiis'; he refers to chapters in the second, third, and last books of the work. Kirkstead (K502) has `Richardus de Cyrencestria de officio ecclesiastico', said to be in seven books.

      K502.1 HENRY DE KIRKESTEDE: Catalogus, c. 1360

  • Richard FitzRalph [†1360], archbishop of Armagh
    48 catalogue entries (7 books).
    • Commentary on the Lombard's Sentences: unpr.; Sharpe, Latin Writers, 478–9; Stegmüller Sent. 719–21.
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      FA8.219b FRIARS: York Austin Friars: Catalogue, 1382, with additions
      SS2.72b (abbrev.) BRIGITTINES: Syon: Class-marks reconstructed from Betson's Index and from erasure
      UC27.4 UNIVERSITY AND COLLEGE LIBRARIES OF CAMBRIDGE: Gonville and Caius College: Leland, c. 1535
    • Contra fratres mendicantes. Such a collection is described in the catalogue of the Austin Friars at York (Friars, 145), and Leland described another belonging to the London Carmelites (Friars, 183). The texts would include the bull Vas electionis (1321) and one or more of FitzRalph's treatises relating to the case in the cardinals' tribunal (1357–8), Defensio curatorum (pr. Louvain 1475 &c.), Quia in propositione nuper facta (unpr.), De audientia confessionum (unpr.) and Libellus Coram nobis (unpr.); on all of which see K. Walsh, Richard FitzRalph in Oxford, Avignon and Armagh (Oxford 1981), 406–51.

    • Ad nouitios, a sermon on Psalm 28, `Afferte Domino &c. Vobis dicitur, nouicii. Attendite, nouicii': PL 196. 285–322. Editions since the 16th cent. have merged various works on particular psalms under the title Adnotationes mysticae in Psalmos (PL 196. 265–404).

    • Tractatus super quosdam Psalmos, inc. `Quare fremuerunt [Ps 2: 1] Quid per gentes que Deum nesciunt': PL 196. 265–74, 277–86, 321–36, 343–6, 365–70, 377–80; J. Châtillon in DS 13. 618–20.   • Robert Winchelsea [†1313], archbishop of Canterbury
    7 catalogue entries (4 books).
    • (?), Commentary on Aristotle's Logica: not known to survive; Sharpe, Latin Writers, 578. The attribution of this work to Robert is Emden's (BRUO 2059); Bale, Catalogus, 1. 39, attributed it to John Winchelsea OFM (†1326; Sharpe, Latin Writers, 346); Leland, who is the only witness to the book, did not record the author's baptismal name but subsequently, in his Scriptores, 320, he attributed it to Thomas Winchelsea.
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      F24.25 (`Winchelsei super logicam stilo scholastico') NEW FRIARS: London-Austin: Leland, c. 1536-40

    • De diuinis officiis: ed. R. Haacke, CCCM 7 (1967). [The entries that name Peter as author are indexed here by inference from two points of evidence, the incipit `Ea quae' (K443.1) and the title given at Reading (B71.31b); Rupert's prologue begins, `Ea que per anni circulum ordine constituto'. The notes included in the editions referred these entries to ps. Alcuin, following the discussion at R74.1. I have found no evidence explicitly to clarify the association of either work, or any other possible candidate, with Peter Damian.]
      Catalogue entryCatalogue
      B71.31b (`liber Petri Damiani de diuinis officiis per circulum anni') BENEDICTINES: THE SHORTER CATALOGUES: Reading: Catalogue, 1192

      R74 (2 copies, one of them = B71.31, attrib. Peter Damian) REGISTRUM ANGLIE: Union catalogue by author and title, early 14th cent.
